Ah, me and my family don't own much animal fiber clothing. I have had some leather shoes, but mostly just cotton and artificial fabrics. Even the "woolly" socks and mittens my mum knits are half plastic lol.
With bugs in my home I worry about my pets if their venomous it can mean risking you pet same with if their poisonous again your risking a puppy or cat who might eat them

In my childhood bedroom a spider lived in the upper corner for a while and regularly crawled to the ceiling right over my bed. took a while to get used to as an 11 year old but I named it Jeffery and when it died I was very upset.

Granary weevils are one of the most yucky creatures that can ever invade your kitchen. I never knew why I never felt the urge to kill spiders. Now I know!

I hate to say this but I have such a terrible fear of spiders but not only do I reach for the shoe but I smash it until it’s most definitely over dead. I will chase a spider around the house, moving furniture if I have to till that thing is super dead.

We live with a tiny spider we've named Charlotte (not very original, I know).  She lives behind a painting hung over the mantle piece in our living room.  She eats flour moths, which we have a lot of because of our parrots' food.  We love Charlotte, but we do wish that she wouldn't leave little piles of dessicated moth corpses on the mantle - so unsightly!

I intentionally let the wolf spiders stay in my home. They eat other spiders, including brown recluse and black widows. So, I prefer to let the wolf spiders stay.  Though, my cats disagree, so the wolf spiders usually don't get to stay for very long.
Most cats and small dogs would (could?) be considered Synanthropic Animals.

3:36 Hey, I see both of those in my garden! Especially the little sparrows, but sometimes we see the bigger starlings too, which are so pretty with the little white star-like dots. And we get a whole load of sparrows in our rosebush throughout most of the day; it's really very lovely. We get other birds too, like pigeons, a pair of blackbirds, some bluetits, a robin, and some occasional dunnocks. One day I even saw a couple of rooks (I think... large corvids anyway) fighting over the bird food I put out, but they never came back unfortunately. I live in England by the way.

0:15 I carefully catch it and put it in a cupboard, because that's where spiders belong! Or I just chase it away, because where spiders belong is out of sight/on the ceiling. I also sometimes put them behind a sofa, or somewhere else out of the way.

(Also please note that the cupboards I put them in are full length cupboards with door-doors (a bit like walk-in closets, although they don't have enough space to walk into) where our gas and electricity are. I'm also pretty confident they could leave if they wanted to as the doors aren't exactly sealed and stop a little way above the floor - there's a small gap at the bottom that is.)

Common house spiders, I'm fine with.
Wolf spiders, less so, thanks. The females are tetchy at best and downright aggressive at their worst, and they're ENORMOUS compared to their mates. The male wolf spider is bloody adorable, and he keeps out of my way. The female stands on my carpet, gesticulates rudely, and will probably try to bite me. So SHE goes.
That said: golden orb spiders make wonderful neighbors. They do not want to be inside, but they'll happily act as your screen door if you let 'em.
Long story short: know your spiders folks, murder the dangerous ones and leave the others alone to eat whatever bugs are getting into your house.

I used to live on a farm and across the farmyard from our house was a granary store and when there was a lot of wheat or barley stored in it, I used to see loads of weevils every year and would often find them on the outside of the bathroom window that overlooks the yard and sometimes inside the bathroom if the window was left open. I don't know if this is the only instance of Synathropic animals going extinct but there was once a mouse on St Kilda island in the north of Scotland, where people used to live. It was known as the St Kilda house mouse (a subspecies of house mouse) and it relied on the the food scraps people left behind as it was thought to have originated on the island on Viking ships and in 1930 when the last people left the island, it quickly went extinct.

Human body lice is actually another example because its thought that they didnt evolve until the invention of clothes. Lice usually can only survive in dense hair or feathers, so the lice we usually have, the Head and Pubic louse, werent able to leave their respective areas on the body. But with the invention and widespread use of clothes, these insects were able to move to other parts of the body and remain unexposed due to clothes protecting them from the elements and from view of the host most of the time.

In Australia we have a large spider called the huntsman.  They can grow to about the span of a smallish human hand -- about 15cm or so from tip to tip -- and live predominantly on house walls, ceilings and cavities.  They do not make webs.  Instead they ambush moths, bugs and sometimes small lizards.  They also not harmful to humans although their largish fangs would probably give you a nasty, infected bite if you were silly enough to threaten one.  They are shy and won't bother you as you are far too big to eat.
Many people are frightened of huntsmen but they are actually the big teddy bear of the spider world and even make a decent alternative pet if you're so inclined.
We don't have so call house spider in S.E.Asia, instead jumping spiders (i think Portia) live in our houses.

I grew up in the Philippines, and I was maybe 12 or 13 when I realized how helpful spiders are.

We had a larger spider, maybe the size of my hand, living in our showers for the longest time. Freaked you out the first time you saw it, but it honestly just sat there and killed cockroaches. Must have made friends with the geckos that would hang out behind picture frames above the TV. These two beautiful "pets" probably kept my whole family from contracting lots of mosquito-borne diseases growing up.

And chances are the 3-foot-long lizard that lived behind the door in the kitchen kept us from contracting some type of rat plague.

I don't know about 'House Spiders ' (Tegenaria spp.) in the rest of the world, but in my part of the UK the indoors is not a safe place for them at all. Spider-appreciating Facebook pages are filled with distressed comment about how beloved 'Tegs' are being eaten by the much more prolific 'Cellar Spider' (Pholcus phalangioides), which appears in every corner left unattended for a day or two and seems to be able to produce hundreds of offspring while, apparently, living on air but for getting lucky with an occasional passing 'Teg'. The long legged Pholcus just ties up the biggest of Tegs before they ever get to within biting range of the larger spider's fangs.

I'm quite surprised when I see a Teg these days. I leave the Pholcus alone to deal with soil gnats from the house plant pots--actual mosquitoes seem to be able to avoid them somehow (Incidentally, both Pholcus, and mosquitoes have a habit of doing 'high speed press ups'. What's that all about? And why do mosquitoes hold two legs off the ground like we keep ski sticks under our arms?)--but it rather looks as if the 'Cellar Spider' has migrated upstairs, as fewer homes have cellars, and the poor old 'traditional' House Spider looks to be doomed.

Second story: Was once given a physical exercise to do wherein you buy a bucket of rice (or a bucket and rice separately) and do motion in it with your hands a couple times a day, to try and strengthen very weird muscles (along with others) in the arms. I was told to keep the bucket shut no matter what, to keep out pests, and even though I listened I still found weevils inside it a couple weeks later. I was always wondering if I kept it open too long doing the exercises, or didn't close it tight enough or what.
Now it seems likely that the real weevils were inside our rice buckets all along. Sadly, no friendship was found in there along with them, so that rice (and pests) got airlocked pretty fast.

I tell you what. It is very obvious that the people that tell you to leave a spider alone that is in your house has never been bitten a venomous spider before. I got tagged by a very mean Brown Recluse or Fiddle Back Spider and it took me a little over 2 years to heal. I still have a nice size hole in my arm where the surgeon had to cut all of the rotten flesh out. So yeah please don't tell me to leave a spider alone. All I could think about is my baby girl getting bit by this damn thing or my wife. I know the differences between the good spiders and bad spiders. Its easy to tell them apart y'all. This is how you can tell and bear with me, I am not an expert by any means. Ok here it is, my little secret of how to tell them apart. A dead spider is a good spider and a spider moving around is a bad spider. Rolled up news papers, shoes and almost anything that is hard will work to kill them. I know I am a mean person. Look the spider will die Anyway. All I do is help speed that process up. I hit the fast forward button and then clean up the mess. I'm sorry this is a really bad joke. I have been bitten and had to have surgery, that part is very much real. Where I live, we have 3 venomous spiders that are native here.
1. Brown Recluse / Fiddle Back
2. The Black Widow
3. This is the Brown Widow and from what I have read about them, they are worse than the Black Widow.
The first time I had ever seen 1 of these, I almost picked her up. I never heard of a Brown Widow before. I thought it was like a king snake or milk snake that looks like a coral snake. My mind is drawing a blank.on the right words. I know that it's mimicry or something like that. If you ever happen to get bitten by a brown recluse, go to the doctor as soon as you can. It will be easier before all the bad stuff happens. Or that is just what my surgeon was saying to me as he was cutting my arm up. Anyway peace out y'all. I hope you never experience that crap, it truly sucks.
